title: Simple Turkey Chili Recipe
description: This turkey chili recipe is made with ground turkey, tomatoes, kidney beans, and spices that make it super flavorful. Even better on the second day!

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Soups, Stews and Chili Recipes Chili Recipes Turkey Chili Recipes Simple Turkey Chili 4.6 (2,362) 1,784 Reviews 263 Photos This turkey chili recipe is very simple but hearty with plenty of flavors — it tastes even better on the second day! I serve this chili with low-fat Cheddar cheese and low-fat sour cream. It's also delicious with crackers. Submitted by Amanda Ingraham Updated on October 14, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 263 263 263 263 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 45 mins Total Time: 1 hr Servings: 8 Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe This hearty turkey chili recipe, made with easy-to-find ingredients and pantry staples, will warm you up from the inside out. Turkey Chili Ingredients It's easy to make this turkey chili recipe with basic ingredients you may already have on hand: · Turkey: This simple turkey chili starts with a pound of ground turkey cooked in olive oil.· Onion and garlic: An onion and a tablespoon of fresh garlic add bold flavor and depth.· Canned vegetables: You'll need canned crushed tomatoes and canned kidney beans.· Spices: The turkey chill is spiced with chili powder, paprika, dried oregano, cayenne pepper, cumin, salt, and black pepper. How to Make Turkey Chili You'll find the full, step-by-step recipe below — but here's a brief overview of what you can expect when you make this comforting homemade turkey chili: 1. Brown the turkey in olive oil. Add the onion and cook until tender.2. Stir in the remaining ingredients.3. Bring to a boil, reduce the heat, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes. Can You Make This Turkey Chili In the Slow Cooker? Yes! This turkey chili recipe is easy to make in the Crock-Pot, if you're looking for a set-it-and-forget-it meal instead of a stovetop dinner. Simply combine all the ingredients in the slow cooker and cook on Low for 6-7 hours or on High for 3-4 hours. What to Serve With Turkey Chili Looking for delicious serving inspiration? Check out one of these recipes that pairs perfectly with turkey chili: · Grilled Cheese Sandwich· Grandmother's Buttermilk Cornbread· Perfect Baked Potato Explore our collection of 16 Side Dishes That Go Great With Chili. How to Store Turkey Chili Store the turkey chili in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to four days. Reheat in the microwave, in the oven, or on the stove. Can You Freeze Turkey Chili? Yes, you can freeze turkey chili. Ladle the leftovers into freezer bags, leaving about an inch of space at the top (the chili will expand as it freezes). Seal, then wrap the whole thing in foil. Freeze flat for up to three months. Thaw in the refrigerator overnight or reheat the frozen chili on the stove. Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise "Great turkey chili recipe," according to Ava Probst. "Easy to make, quick and tasty. I've always thought chili should be made with beef but I prefer this turkey recipe!" "I've made this turkey chili several times and we love it," says Brian M. "I add a can of black beans to go along with the kidney beans. I also cut up a couple of bell peppers to throw in. These additions make it a bit heartier." "It was so easy and absolutely delicious," raves Trish. "I froze it and had it for my work lunches for a while. I will definitely make this again." Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings 1 ½ teaspoons olive oil 1 pound ground turkey 1 onion, chopped 2 cups water 1 (28 ounce) can canned crushed tomatoes 1 (16 ounce) can canned kidney beans - drained, rinsed, and mashed 1 tablespoon garlic, minced 2 tablespoons chili powder ½ teaspoon paprika ½ teaspoon dried oregano ½ teaspoon ground cayenne pepper ½ teaspoon ground cumin ½ teaspoon salt ½ teaspoon ground black pepper Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add turkey; cook and stir until evenly browned, 6 to 8 minutes. Stir in onion and cook until tender. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Add water; mix in tomatoes, kidney beans, and garlic. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stir in chili powder, paprika, oregano, cayenne pepper, cumin, salt, and pepper. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 4,390 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Simple Turkey Chili 01 of 263 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 263 Photo by  Jeanette Wiederhold 04/16/2024 Very easy to follow. I used up what I had in fridge. Corn,bell pepper. I used chili sauce in place of tomatoes(kidney disease) and cannellini beans. Very flavorful. 03 of 263 Photo by  dishstreet 02/10/2024 Worth the effort Nice recipe for red turkey chili. Turned out the best I've ever made. I did substitute for what I had. Added 2 ribs celery and 1/2 chopped yellow sweet pepper (use up veggies). Used 28 oz diced tomatoes but I blended them. Added handful of cilantro and a 4 oz can chopped green mild chilies. Threw in a generous T of fresh pico de Gallo with mild jalapeno again using up veggies. Followed the recipe seasoning except my dau showed up as I was starting and gave me 1T sample of ancho chili powder which I've never used. Used my regular for the 2nd T. Added better than bouillon chicken stock concentrate with the water. Used 2 cans beans: crushed 1can pinto beans and added can of whole red kidney. I add the bean broth always to chili gives it flavor and substance. Wouldn't waste it! Anyway I just made it work to what I had. End result is best ever. I will keep this because it has a good structure of ratios of ingredients which is the part I always forget. 04 of 263 Photo by  Sherry Buckingham 01/24/2024 A keeper! Doubled the beans and halved the water. Fabulous. 05 of 263 Photo by  SpiffyPasta1291 12/07/2023 Have to be honest haven’t tasted it yet, but it smells good. I did follow everything there’s only one I added a package of Goya seasoning which I usually use in almost everything. I had no Cayenne so I use red pepper flakes for now I will give it a five star for its easiness easiest kind of ever made 06 of 263 Photo by  Soup Loving Nicole 11/28/2023 Made as written to begin with this and it was pretty good. I'll admit that I have never mashed a can of beans for chili and I was hesitant. Because others say this was thin, I bought an additional can of beans. I mashed one as directed and then added another not mashed. Maybe because I used 2 can of beans instead of just 1 but this didn't turn out too thin for me as others mentioned. It was actually a bit thicker than I typically like my chili but the leftovers were the perfect consistency for Frito Pie. Double the beans, add more salt, and you've got a simple well balanced chili. It's a good base but just needs a few tweaks. 07 of 263 Photo by  jessytucker88 12/06/2021 08 of 263 Photo by  natlili 10/05/2021 Love it and so does the whole family! 09 of 263 Photo by  karamia78 09/03/2021 10 of 263 Photo by  karamia78 09/03/2021 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Spicy Turkey Chili 69 Ratings Fantastic Black Bean Chili 1,055 Ratings Laura's Quick Slow Cooker Turkey Chili 1,673 Ratings Elk Chili 101 Ratings Slow Cooker Turkey Chili with Kidney Beans 3 Ratings Kickin' Spicy Turkey Beer Chili 19 Ratings Best Yet Turkey Chili 108 Ratings Michelle's Blonde Chicken Chili 295 Ratings Vegetarian Chili 286 Ratings Turkey and Butternut Squash Chili 491 Ratings Incredibly Easy Vegetarian Chili 717 Ratings Chicken and Corn Chili 789 Ratings Black Bean Chili 364 Ratings Turkey-Lentil Chili 109 Ratings Veggie Vegetarian Chili 318 Ratings Vegetarian Black Bean Chili 12 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family.
